trans-unit.source: Elastic Scale Security Configurations
trans-unit.target: Elastic Scale Security Configurations

trans-unit.source: Set up x409 certificates for encryption
trans-unit.target: Set up x409 certificates for encryption

trans-unit.source: To use the Split/Merge service, you must correctly configure security.
trans-unit.target: To use the Split/Merge service, you must correctly configure security.

trans-unit.source: The service is part of the Elastic Scale feature of Microsoft Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The service is part of the Elastic Scale feature of Microsoft Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Elastic Scale Split and Merge Service Tutorial</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Elastic Scale Split and Merge Service Tutorial</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Certificates are configured in two ways.
trans-unit.target: Certificates are configured in two ways.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>To Configure the SSL Certificate</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>To Configure the SSL Certificate</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>To Configure Client Certificates</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>To Configure Client Certificates</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Certificates can be obtained from public Certificate Authorities (CAs) or from the <linkText>Windows Certificate Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Certificates can be obtained from public Certificate Authorities (CAs) or from the <linkText>Windows Certificate Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: These are the preferred methods to obtain certificates.
trans-unit.target: These are the preferred methods to obtain certificates.

trans-unit.source: If those options are not available, you can generate self-signed certificates.
trans-unit.target: If those options are not available, you can generate self-signed certificates.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>makecert.exe</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>makecert.exe</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>pvk2pfx.exe</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>pvk2pfx.exe</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: From a Developer Command Prompt for Visual Studios, see <linkText>Visual Studio Command Prompt</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: From a Developer Command Prompt for Visual Studios, see <linkText>Visual Studio Command Prompt</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: If installed, go to:
trans-unit.target: If installed, go to:

trans-unit.source: Get the WDK from <linkText>Windows 8.1: Download kits and tools</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Get the WDK from <linkText>Windows 8.1: Download kits and tools</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: A SSL certificate is required to encrypt the communication and authenticate the server.
trans-unit.target: A SSL certificate is required to encrypt the communication and authenticate the server.

trans-unit.source: Access to the service endpoints can be restricted to specific ranges of IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: Access to the service endpoints can be restricted to specific ranges of IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: A certificate is required to encrypt the credentials that are stored in the metadata store.
trans-unit.target: A certificate is required to encrypt the credentials that are stored in the metadata store.

trans-unit.source: Choose the most applicable of the three scenarios below, and execute all its steps:
trans-unit.target: Choose the most applicable of the three scenarios below, and execute all its steps:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a Self-Signed Certificate</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a Self-Signed Certificate</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create PFX file for Self-Signed Encryption Certificate</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Upload Encryption Certificate to Cloud Service</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Update Encryption Certificate in Service Configuration File</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Export Encryption Certificate From Certificate Store</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: The default configuration denies all access to the HTTP endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The default configuration denies all access to the HTTP endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This is the recommended setting, since the requests to these endpoints may carry sensitive information like database credentials.
trans-unit.target: This is the recommended setting, since the requests to these endpoints may carry sensitive information like database credentials.

trans-unit.source: The default configuration allows all access to the HTTPS endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The default configuration allows all access to the HTTPS endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This setting may be restricted further.
trans-unit.target: This setting may be restricted further.

trans-unit.source: The group of access control rules that apply to and endpoint are configured in the section in the service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: The group of access control rules that apply to and endpoint are configured in the section in the service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: The rules in an access control group are configured in a <AccessControl name=""> section of the service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: The rules in an access control group are configured in a <AccessControl name=""> section of the service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: The format is explained in Network Access Control Lists documentation.
trans-unit.target: The format is explained in Network Access Control Lists documentation.

trans-unit.source: For example, to allow only IPs in the range 100.100.0.0 to 100.100.255.255 to access the HTTPS endpoint, the rules would look like this:
trans-unit.target: For example, to allow only IPs in the range 100.100.0.0 to 100.100.255.255 to access the HTTPS endpoint, the rules would look like this:

trans-unit.source: There are two different mechanisms supported to detect and prevent Denial of Service attacks:
trans-unit.target: There are two different mechanisms supported to detect and prevent Denial of Service attacks:

trans-unit.source: Restrict number of concurrent requests per remote host (off by default)
trans-unit.target: Restrict number of concurrent requests per remote host (off by default)

trans-unit.source: Restrict rate of access per remote host (on by default)
trans-unit.target: Restrict rate of access per remote host (on by default)

trans-unit.source: These are based on the features further documented in Dynamic IP Security in IIS.
trans-unit.target: These are based on the features further documented in Dynamic IP Security in IIS.

trans-unit.source: When changing this configuration beware of the following factors:
trans-unit.target: When changing this configuration beware of the following factors:

trans-unit.source: The behavior of proxies and Network Address Translation devices over the remote host information
trans-unit.target: The behavior of proxies and Network Address Translation devices over the remote host information

trans-unit.source: Each request to any resource in the web role is considered (e.g. loading scripts, images, etc)
trans-unit.target: Each request to any resource in the web role is considered (e.g. loading scripts, images, etc)

trans-unit.source: The settings that configure this behavior are:
trans-unit.target: The settings that configure this behavior are:

trans-unit.source: Change DynamicIpRestrictionDenyByConcurrentRequests to true to enable this protection.
trans-unit.target: Change DynamicIpRestrictionDenyByConcurrentRequests to true to enable this protection.

trans-unit.source: The settings that configure this behavior are:
trans-unit.target: The settings that configure this behavior are:

trans-unit.source: The following setting configures the response to a denied request:
trans-unit.target: The following setting configures the response to a denied request:

trans-unit.source: This topic is for reference only.
trans-unit.target: This topic is for reference only.

trans-unit.source: Please follow the configuration steps outlined in:
trans-unit.target: Please follow the configuration steps outlined in:

trans-unit.source: Configure the SSL certificate
trans-unit.target: Configure the SSL certificate

trans-unit.source: Configure client certificates
trans-unit.target: Configure client certificates

trans-unit.source: Execute:
trans-unit.target: Execute:

trans-unit.source: To customize:
trans-unit.target: To customize:

trans-unit.source: -n with the service URL.
trans-unit.target: -n with the service URL.

trans-unit.source: Wildcards ("CN=*.cloudapp.net") and alternative names ("CN=myservice1.cloudapp.net, CN=myservice2.cloudapp.net") are supported.
trans-unit.target: Wildcards ("CN=*.cloudapp.net") and alternative names ("CN=myservice1.cloudapp.net, CN=myservice2.cloudapp.net") are supported.

trans-unit.source: -e with the certificate expiration date Create a strong password and specify it when prompted.
trans-unit.target: -e with the certificate expiration date Create a strong password and specify it when prompted.

trans-unit.source: Execute:
trans-unit.target: Execute:

trans-unit.source: Enter password and then export certificate with these options:
trans-unit.target: Enter password and then export certificate with these options:

trans-unit.source: Yes, export the private key
trans-unit.target: Yes, export the private key

trans-unit.source: Export all extended properties
trans-unit.target: Export all extended properties

trans-unit.source: Find certificate
trans-unit.target: Find certificate

trans-unit.source: Click Actions -> All tasks -> Export…
trans-unit.target: Click Actions -> All tasks -> Export…

trans-unit.source: Export certificate into a .PFX file with these options:
trans-unit.target: Export certificate into a .PFX file with these options:

trans-unit.source: Yes, export the private key
trans-unit.target: Yes, export the private key

trans-unit.source: Include all certificates in the certification path if possible *Export all extended properties
trans-unit.target: Include all certificates in the certification path if possible *Export all extended properties

trans-unit.source: Upload certificate with the existing or generated .PFX file with the SSL key pair:
trans-unit.target: Upload certificate with the existing or generated .PFX file with the SSL key pair:

trans-unit.target: Enter the password protecting the private key information

trans-unit.source: Update the thumbprint value of the following setting in the service configuration file with the thumbprint of the certificate uploaded to the cloud service:
trans-unit.target: Update the thumbprint value of the following setting in the service configuration file with the thumbprint of the certificate uploaded to the cloud service:

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps in all account/machine that will communicate with the service:
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps in all account/machine that will communicate with the service:

trans-unit.source: Double-click the .CER file in Windows Explorer
trans-unit.target: Double-click the .CER file in Windows Explorer

trans-unit.source: In the Certificate dialog, click Install Certificate…
trans-unit.target: In the Certificate dialog, click Install Certificate…

trans-unit.source: Import certificate into the Trusted Root Certification Authorities store
trans-unit.target: Import certificate into the Trusted Root Certification Authorities store

trans-unit.source: Only client certificate-based authentication is supported and disabling it will allow for public access to the service endpoints, unless other mechanisms are in place (e.g. Microsoft Azure Virtual Network).
trans-unit.target: Only client certificate-based authentication is supported and disabling it will allow for public access to the service endpoints, unless other mechanisms are in place (e.g. Microsoft Azure Virtual Network).

trans-unit.source: Change these settings to false in the service configuration file to turn the feature off:
trans-unit.target: Change these settings to false in the service configuration file to turn the feature off:

trans-unit.source: Then, copy the same thumbprint as the SSL certificate in the CA certificate setting:
trans-unit.target: Then, copy the same thumbprint as the SSL certificate in the CA certificate setting:

trans-unit.source: Execute the following steps to create a self-signed certificate to act as a Certification Authority:
trans-unit.target: Execute the following steps to create a self-signed certificate to act as a Certification Authority:

trans-unit.source: To customize it
trans-unit.target: To customize it

trans-unit.source: -e with the certification expiration date
trans-unit.target: -e with the certification expiration date

trans-unit.source: All client certificates must have been issued by a Certification Authority trusted by the service.
trans-unit.target: All client certificates must have been issued by a Certification Authority trusted by the service.

trans-unit.source: Find the public key to the Certification Authority that issued the client certificates that are going to be used for authentication in order to upload it to the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Find the public key to the Certification Authority that issued the client certificates that are going to be used for authentication in order to upload it to the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: If the file with the public key is not available, export it from the certificate store:
trans-unit.target: If the file with the public key is not available, export it from the certificate store:

trans-unit.source: Find certificate
trans-unit.target: Find certificate

trans-unit.source: Search for a client certificate issued by the same Certification Authority
trans-unit.target: Search for a client certificate issued by the same Certification Authority

trans-unit.source: Double-click the certificate.
trans-unit.target: Double-click the certificate.

trans-unit.source: Select the Certification Path tab in the Certificate dialog.
trans-unit.target: Select the Certification Path tab in the Certificate dialog.

trans-unit.source: Double-click the CA entry in the path.
trans-unit.target: Double-click the CA entry in the path.

trans-unit.source: Take notes of the certificate properties.
trans-unit.target: Take notes of the certificate properties.

trans-unit.source: Close the Certificate dialog.
trans-unit.target: Close the Certificate dialog.

trans-unit.source: Find certificate
trans-unit.target: Find certificate

trans-unit.source: Search for the CA noted above.
trans-unit.target: Search for the CA noted above.

trans-unit.source: Click Actions -> All tasks -> Export…
trans-unit.target: Click Actions -> All tasks -> Export…

trans-unit.source: Export certificate into a .CER with these options:
trans-unit.target: Export certificate into a .CER with these options:

trans-unit.source: No, do not export the private key
trans-unit.target: No, do not export the private key

trans-unit.source: Include all certificates in the certification path if possible.
trans-unit.target: Include all certificates in the certification path if possible.

trans-unit.source: Export all extended properties.
trans-unit.target: Export all extended properties.

trans-unit.source: Upload certificate with the existing or generated .CER file with the CA public key.
trans-unit.target: Upload certificate with the existing or generated .CER file with the CA public key.

trans-unit.source: Update the thumbprint value of the following setting in the service configuration file with the thumbprint of the certificate uploaded to the cloud service:
trans-unit.target: Update the thumbprint value of the following setting in the service configuration file with the thumbprint of the certificate uploaded to the cloud service:

trans-unit.target: Update the value of the following setting with the same thumbprint:

trans-unit.source: Each individual authorized to access the service should have a client certificate issued for his/hers exclusive use and should choose his/hers own strong password to protect its private key.
trans-unit.target: Each individual authorized to access the service should have a client certificate issued for his/hers exclusive use and should choose his/hers own strong password to protect its private key.

trans-unit.source: The following steps must be executed in the same machine where the self-signed CA certificate was generated and stored:
trans-unit.target: The following steps must be executed in the same machine where the self-signed CA certificate was generated and stored:

trans-unit.source: Customizing:
trans-unit.target: Customizing:

trans-unit.source: -n with an ID for to the client that will be authenticated with this certificate
trans-unit.target: -n with an ID for to the client that will be authenticated with this certificate

trans-unit.source: -e with the certificate expiration date
trans-unit.target: -e with the certificate expiration date

trans-unit.source: MyID.pvk and MyID.cer with unique filenames for this client certificate
trans-unit.target: MyID.pvk and MyID.cer with unique filenames for this client certificate

trans-unit.source: This command will prompt for a password to be created and then used once.
trans-unit.target: This command will prompt for a password to be created and then used once.

trans-unit.source: Use a strong password.
trans-unit.target: Use a strong password.

trans-unit.target: For each generated client certificate, execute:

trans-unit.target: Customizing:

trans-unit.target: Enter password and then export certificate with these options:

trans-unit.source: Yes, export the private key
trans-unit.target: Yes, export the private key

trans-unit.source: Export all extended properties
trans-unit.target: Export all extended properties

trans-unit.source: The individual to whom this certificate is being issued should choose the export password
trans-unit.target: The individual to whom this certificate is being issued should choose the export password

trans-unit.source: Each individual for whom a client certificate has been issued should import the key pair in the machines he/she will use to communicate with the service:
trans-unit.target: Each individual for whom a client certificate has been issued should import the key pair in the machines he/she will use to communicate with the service:

trans-unit.source: Double-click the .PFX file in Windows Explorer
trans-unit.target: Double-click the .PFX file in Windows Explorer

trans-unit.source: Import certificate into the Personal store with at least this option:
trans-unit.target: Import certificate into the Personal store with at least this option:

trans-unit.source: Include all extended properties checked
trans-unit.target: Include all extended properties checked

trans-unit.source: Each individual for whom a client certificate has been issued must follow these steps in order to obtain the thumbprint of his/hers certificate which will be added to the service configuration file:
trans-unit.target: Each individual for whom a client certificate has been issued must follow these steps in order to obtain the thumbprint of his/hers certificate which will be added to the service configuration file:

trans-unit.source: Run certmgr.exe
trans-unit.target: Run certmgr.exe

trans-unit.source: Select the Personal tab
trans-unit.target: Select the Personal tab

trans-unit.source: Double-click the client certificate to be used for authentication
trans-unit.target: Double-click the client certificate to be used for authentication

trans-unit.source: In the Certificate dialog that opens, select the Details tab
trans-unit.target: In the Certificate dialog that opens, select the Details tab

trans-unit.source: Make sure Show is displaying All
trans-unit.target: Make sure Show is displaying All

trans-unit.source: Select the field named Thumbprint in the list
trans-unit.target: Select the field named Thumbprint in the list

trans-unit.source: Copy the value of the thumbprint * Delete non-visible Unicode characters in front of the first digit * Delete all spaces
trans-unit.target: Copy the value of the thumbprint * Delete non-visible Unicode characters in front of the first digit * Delete all spaces

trans-unit.source: Update the value of the following setting in the service configuration file with a comma-separated list of the thumbprints of the client certificates allowed access to the service:
trans-unit.target: Update the value of the following setting in the service configuration file with a comma-separated list of the thumbprints of the client certificates allowed access to the service:

trans-unit.source: The default setting does not check with the Certification Authority for client certificate revocation status.
trans-unit.target: The default setting does not check with the Certification Authority for client certificate revocation status.

trans-unit.target: To turn on the checks, if the Certification Authority which issued the client certificates supports such checks, change the following setting with one of the values defined in the X509RevocationMode Enumeration:

trans-unit.source: Configure the SSL certificate
trans-unit.target: Configure the SSL certificate

trans-unit.source: Configure client certificates
trans-unit.target: Configure client certificates

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Run mmc.exe.
trans-unit.target: Run mmc.exe.

trans-unit.source: File -> Add/Remove Snap-in…
trans-unit.target: File -> Add/Remove Snap-in…

trans-unit.source: Select Certificates.
trans-unit.target: Select Certificates.

trans-unit.source: Click Add.
trans-unit.target: Click Add.

trans-unit.source: Choose the certificate store location.
trans-unit.target: Choose the certificate store location.

trans-unit.source: Click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Expand Certificates.
trans-unit.target: Expand Certificates.

trans-unit.source: Expand the certificate store node.
trans-unit.target: Expand the certificate store node.

trans-unit.source: Expand the Certificate child node.
trans-unit.target: Expand the Certificate child node.

trans-unit.source: Select a certificate in the list.
trans-unit.target: Select a certificate in the list.

trans-unit.source: In the Certificate Export Wizard:
trans-unit.target: In the Certificate Export Wizard:

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: Select Yes, then Export the private key.
trans-unit.target: Select Yes, then Export the private key.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: Select the desired output file format.
trans-unit.target: Select the desired output file format.

trans-unit.source: Check the desired options.
trans-unit.target: Check the desired options.

trans-unit.source: Check Password.
trans-unit.target: Check Password.

trans-unit.source: Enter a strong password and confirm it.
trans-unit.target: Enter a strong password and confirm it.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: Type or browse a filename where to store the certificate (use a .PFX extension).
trans-unit.target: Type or browse a filename where to store the certificate (use a .PFX extension).

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: Click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: In the Certificate Import Wizard:
trans-unit.target: In the Certificate Import Wizard:

trans-unit.source: Select the store location.
trans-unit.target: Select the store location.

trans-unit.source: Select Current User if only processes running under current user will access the service
trans-unit.target: Select Current User if only processes running under current user will access the service

trans-unit.source: Select Local Machine if other processes in this computer will access the service
trans-unit.target: Select Local Machine if other processes in this computer will access the service

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: If importing from a file, confirm the file path.
trans-unit.target: If importing from a file, confirm the file path.

trans-unit.source: If importing a .PFX file:
trans-unit.target: If importing a .PFX file:

trans-unit.source: Enter the password protecting the private key
trans-unit.target: Enter the password protecting the private key

trans-unit.source: Select import options
trans-unit.target: Select import options

trans-unit.source: Select "Place" certificates in the following store
trans-unit.target: Select "Place" certificates in the following store

trans-unit.source: Click Browse.
trans-unit.target: Click Browse.

trans-unit.source: Select the desired store.
trans-unit.target: Select the desired store.

trans-unit.source: Click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish.

trans-unit.source: If the Trusted Root Certification Authority store was chosen, click Yes.
trans-unit.target: If the Trusted Root Certification Authority store was chosen, click Yes.

trans-unit.source: Click OK on all dialog windows.
trans-unit.target: Click OK on all dialog windows.

trans-unit.source: In the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: In the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Select Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: Select Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: Select the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Select the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: On the top menu, click Certificates.
trans-unit.target: On the top menu, click Certificates.

trans-unit.source: On the bottom bar, click Upload.
trans-unit.target: On the bottom bar, click Upload.

trans-unit.source: Select the certificate file.
trans-unit.target: Select the certificate file.

trans-unit.source: If it is a .PFX file, enter the password for the private key.
trans-unit.target: If it is a .PFX file, enter the password for the private key.

trans-unit.source: Once completed, copy the certificate thumbprint from the new entry in the list.
trans-unit.target: Once completed, copy the certificate thumbprint from the new entry in the list.

trans-unit.source: The SSL settings described in this document encrypt communication between the service and its clients when the HTTPS endpoint is used.
trans-unit.target: The SSL settings described in this document encrypt communication between the service and its clients when the HTTPS endpoint is used.

trans-unit.source: This is important since credentials for database access and potentially other sensitive information are contained in the communication.
trans-unit.target: This is important since credentials for database access and potentially other sensitive information are contained in the communication.

trans-unit.source: Note, however, that the service persists internal status, including credentials, in its internal tables in the Microsoft Azure SQL database that you have provided for metadata storage in your Microsoft Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Note, however, that the service persists internal status, including credentials, in its internal tables in the Microsoft Azure SQL database that you have provided for metadata storage in your Microsoft Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: That database was defined as part of the following setting in your service configuration file (.CSCFG file):
trans-unit.target: That database was defined as part of the following setting in your service configuration file (.CSCFG file):

trans-unit.source: Credentials stored in this database are encrypted.
trans-unit.target: Credentials stored in this database are encrypted.

trans-unit.source: However, as a best practice, ensure that both web and worker roles of your service deployments are kept up to date and secure as they both have access to the metadata database and the certificate used for encryption and decryption of stored credentials.
trans-unit.target: However, as a best practice, ensure that both web and worker roles of your service deployments are kept up to date and secure as they both have access to the metadata database and the certificate used for encryption and decryption of stored credentials.
